Line 74: Line 74:
== Foundation ==
== Foundation ==
  +
[[File:Abu al-Ila Madi.jpg|thumb|Abu al-Ila Madi]]
It was founded by {{link-interwiki|en=Abu al-Ila Madi|lang=ar|lang_title=Ø£Ø¨Ù Ø§ÙØ¹ÙØ§ ÙØ§Ø¶Ù}} in 1996 as a splinter group of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], whom Madi accused of having "narrow political horizons." The creation of al-Wasat was criticized by the Brotherhood, which said Madi was trying to split the movement.<ref name="Reuters">{{Cite news |title=New party shows deep political change in new Egypt |author=Mikhail, Sarah |author2=Perry, Tom |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/19/us-egypt-idUSTRE70O3UW20110219 |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref> It was also not well received by the Egyptian government, which brought its founders before a [[Military tribunal|military court]] on the charge of setting up a party as an Islamist front. Al-Wasat tried to gain an official license four times between 1996 and 2009, but its application was rejected each time by the political parties committee, which was chaired by a leading member of the ruling [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]].<ref name="Reuters"/> Political parties formed on the basis of religion have been banned by the [[Constitution of Egypt|Egyptian constitution]] since an amendment to Article 5 was [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2007|approved in 2007]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cabinet.gov.eg/AboutEgypt/HTML/Constit_update2007_e.pdf |title=Constitutional Amendments of 2007 |publisher=[[Cabinet of Egypt]] |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]] |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref>
It was founded by {{link-interwiki|en=Abu al-Ila Madi|lang=ar|lang_title=Ø£Ø¨Ù Ø§ÙØ¹ÙØ§ ÙØ§Ø¶Ù}} in 1996 as a splinter group of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], whom Madi accused of having "narrow political horizons." The creation of al-Wasat was criticized by the Brotherhood, which said Madi was trying to split the movement.<ref name="Reuters">{{Cite news |title=New party shows deep political change in new Egypt |author=Mikhail, Sarah |author2=Perry, Tom |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/19/us-egypt-idUSTRE70O3UW20110219 |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref> It was also not well received by the Egyptian government, which brought its founders before a [[Military tribunal|military court]] on the charge of setting up a party as an Islamist front. Al-Wasat tried to gain an official license four times between 1996 and 2009, but its application was rejected each time by the political parties committee, which was chaired by a leading member of the ruling [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]].<ref name="Reuters"/> Political parties formed on the basis of religion have been banned by the [[Constitution of Egypt|Egyptian constitution]] since an amendment to Article 5 was [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2007|approved in 2007]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cabinet.gov.eg/AboutEgypt/HTML/Constit_update2007_e.pdf |title=Constitutional Amendments of 2007 |publisher=[[Cabinet of Egypt]] |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]] |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref>
